description:
Photobacterium damselae subsp. damselae is a Gram-negative, halophilic (salt-loving) bacterium belonging to the family Vibrionaceae. It is a facultative anaerobe, meaning it can grow both in the presence and absence of oxygen.

This subspecies is primarily known for its ability to cause infections in a variety of marine organisms, including fish, shellfish, and marine mammals. It has been associated with outbreaks of disease in aquaculture settings, where it can lead to significant economic losses.

Photobacterium damselae subsp. damselae is a motile bacterium, with the ability to produce a variety of virulence factors, such as hemolysin and cytotoxins, which contribute to its pathogenicity. It can also form biofilms, which can enhance its survival and persistence in aquatic environments.

The bacterium is typically found in warm, coastal waters and is considered an opportunistic pathogen, often infecting hosts that are already stressed or immunocompromised. It can be transmitted through direct contact with contaminated water or infected animals, as well as through the consumption of undercooked seafood.

Understanding the biology and epidemiology of Photobacterium damselae subsp. damselae is important for the effective management and prevention of the diseases it can cause in aquatic environments and the seafood industry.
